content.title: Understanding AC Voltage Measurements
content.content:
When we measure AC, we can describe the voltage in **several different ways**. Each measurement tells us something different about the waveform.

**Why Multiple Measurements?**
Unlike DC (which has one steady voltage), AC constantly changes. We need different ways to describe its behavior:
- How high does it go? (peak)
- How much does it vary? (peak-to-peak)
- What's the effective power? (RMS)
- How long is one cycle? (period)

**The Most Important: RMS**
**RMS (Root Mean Square)** is the most useful measurement because it tells us the **effective value** — the voltage that produces the same heating/power effect as DC.

- When we say "UK mains is 230V", we mean **230V RMS**
- RMS is what multimeters show (in AC mode)
- RMS is what equipment ratings use
- Formula: **RMS = 0.707 × peak** (you don't need to calculate this at Level 2)

**Peak Voltage**
The **peak** is the maximum voltage reached in one direction.

- UK mains: **325V peak** (even though we call it "230V")
- Peak = 1.414 × RMS
- Important for insulation ratings and safety clearances
- Capacitors need peak voltage ratings, not RMS

**Peak-to-Peak Voltage**
The **peak-to-peak** is the total voltage swing from top to bottom.

- Peak-to-peak = 2 × peak
- UK mains: 650V peak-to-peak (325V positive to 325V negative)
- Useful for oscilloscope measurements
- Shows the full range of voltage variation

content.title: Time Measurements: Period and Frequency
content.content:
AC sine waves repeat in a regular pattern. We can measure this repetition in two ways: **period** (time) or **frequency** (cycles per second).

**Period (T)**
The **period** is the time taken for **one complete cycle**.

- Symbol: T
- Units: seconds (s), often milliseconds (ms)
- UK mains: **T = 0.02 seconds = 20 ms**
- One cycle = positive peak → zero → negative peak → zero → back to start

**Frequency (f)**
The **frequency** is the number of cycles per second.

- Symbol: f
- Units: hertz (Hz)
- UK mains: **f = 50 Hz** (50 cycles per second)
- Already covered in lesson 202-7A

**The Relationship: Period and Frequency**
Period and frequency are **inversely related** — when one goes up, the other goes down.

**Formula:** **T = 1/f** (period = 1 divided by frequency)

**Examples:**
- 50 Hz → T = 1/50 = 0.02 s (20 ms)
- 60 Hz → T = 1/60 = 0.0167 s (16.7 ms)
- 1000 Hz (1 kHz) → T = 1/1000 = 0.001 s (1 ms)

**At Level 2, you should know:**
- UK mains is 50 Hz (frequency)
- One cycle takes 20 ms (period)
- T = 1/f (the relationship)

**You don't need to calculate periods for unusual frequencies at this level.**

content.title: Average Voltage: Why It's Zero
content.content:
**What is Average Voltage?**
The **average voltage** is the mathematical average over one complete cycle. For a pure sine wave, this average is **zero**.

**Why Zero?**
A symmetrical AC waveform spends equal time positive and negative:
- First half of cycle: voltage is **positive** (e.g., +325V down to 0V)
- Second half of cycle: voltage is **negative** (e.g., 0V down to -325V)
- The positive and negative halves **cancel out exactly**
- Mathematical average = 0V

**But AC Clearly Does Work!**
This seems confusing — if the average is zero, how does AC power anything?

**The answer: Power depends on RMS, not average.**
- Current and voltage are both reversing together
- Power = V × I, and this is always positive (both forward, or both backward)
- The **heating effect** doesn't cancel out
- That's why we use RMS, not average, for AC power

**Average Voltage for Rectified AC**
If you convert AC to DC (using a rectifier), you get a **pulsating DC** that's always positive. Now the average is **not zero** — it's about 0.637 × peak.

**At Level 2:**
- Know that average voltage for pure AC = 0V
- Understand this is because positive cancels negative
- Recognize that RMS is the useful value, not average
- You don't need to calculate average values

**Summary Table:**

| Measurement | UK Mains Example | When Used |
|-------------|------------------|----------|
| **RMS** | 230V | Equipment ratings, power calculations |
| **Peak** | 325V | Insulation ratings, capacitor voltage |
| **Peak-to-Peak** | 650V | Oscilloscope measurements |
| **Average** | 0V | (Not useful for pure AC) |
| **Period** | 20 ms | Timing calculations |
| **Frequency** | 50 Hz | Standard specification |

content.title: Worked Example: Interpreting AC Measurements
content.given: An AC supply is specified as 230V, 50 Hz. A multimeter shows 230V. An oscilloscope shows the waveform reaches +325V and -325V.

steps.description: Identify what the "230V" specification means. This is the RMS (effective) voltage. Equipment ratings and specifications almost always use RMS.
Identify what the multimeter shows. In AC mode, multimeters display RMS voltage. The multimeter reading confirms the specification.
Identify what the oscilloscope shows. The scope displays the actual waveform, so we can see the peak values: +325V and -325V.
Verify the relationship between RMS and peak. For a sine wave, peak ≈ 1.414 × RMS (or RMS ≈ 0.707 × peak).
Calculate the period from the frequency. Period T = 1/f.

content.notes: When working with AC: specifications and meters almost always show RMS. Oscilloscopes show the actual waveform with peak values. Both are correct — they're just different ways of describing the same AC supply.

content.title: Guided Practice (We Do)
content.problem: A device is rated "110V AC, 60 Hz". You measure the waveform on an oscilloscope and see it reaches a maximum of +155V and a minimum of -155V.

steps.prompt: What type of voltage does the "110V" rating represent: RMS, peak, or peak-to-peak?
steps.hint: Equipment ratings almost always use RMS (the effective voltage).

steps.prompt: What is the peak voltage you observed on the oscilloscope?
steps.hint: The peak is the maximum voltage in one direction.
Peak-to-peak is the total voltage from positive peak to negative peak. Add the magnitudes: 155 + 155.

steps.prompt: Calculate the period T (in seconds) for a 60 Hz supply. Use T = 1/f.
Are these measurements consistent? Does RMS ≈ 0.707 × peak?
